title: Monday, 30th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

I guess we should have a pic of this, before it disappears

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

The LME ring, complete with red sofas

PM11:03am

The new CEO there has decided they have to test computers instead of open outcry.

PM11:03am

Just a trial at the moment

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But seems inevitable, I suspect.

PM11:04am

Henry Sanderson has the story

PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-8c12-5661783e5589

11:04 am
PM11:04am

You ever seen the Ring in person Bryce?

PM11:04am

The LME trading floor, that is

PM11:05am

I haven't

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Me neither, which makes it rather difficult to be nostalgic about it.

PM11:06am

Truth is that all open out cry trading is prone to abuse

PM11:06am

But then you just swap for different kinds of abuse with HFT etc

11:06 am
PM11:06am

But you are right. Let's not be nostalgic. Let's get off the red sofas

undefined
PM11:07am

So...

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Footsie off a bit, sterling up a bit. Not related, UBS will have us believe.

PM11:07am

Big tech was flying overnight in the US

PM11:07am

Apple up 3/4%

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Google up 5% (!)

PM11:08am

$1019

PM11:08am

American fixate on stock prices rising through marks like that

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Tech earnings wrap here for anyone who needs a reminder: https://www.ft.com...-8c12-5661783e5589

BE11:10am

Facebook and Alibaba to come this week, right?

PM11:10am

Yes, think s. All forecasts of the death of the Iphone are proving premature

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Think so.

PM11:10am

Even things like Snap were up 7% overnight

PM11:11am

Twitter mentioned on the right

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Yeah that was up almost 7% as well

PM11:12am

Gone from $17 to 22$ in two days.

PM11:12am

Why? Cos its tech

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Well, no. Because its numbers were solidly ahead and there's a reasonable faith from the Street that management's moving things in the right direction, finally.

BE11:13am

Revenue up q-on-q. DAU turning positive ....

PM11:13am

Fair enough

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Though the numbers beat largely on cost cuts, which is a tougher story to sell.

BE11:14am

Though in exchange for slower growth you're only paying 14 times 2018 for Twitter versus peers at 16 times.

BE11:15am

That's EV-EBITDA, to be clear. 14 times.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, let's not get bogged down with all that.

undefined
BE11:15am

So, heading back to the UK .......

11:16 am
BE11:16am

We can do the classics. There's DPL, there's Easyjet, there's retail .....

BE11:16am

... there are bookies, post the weekend press saying very nearly nothing.

PM11:17am

And there's HSBC

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Maybe go in backwards, start with the bookies

BE11:17am

Certainly. We're getting the Triennial Review of gaming machine stakes before the open tomorrow, according to the Times.

BE11:18am

https://www.thetim...stakecut-8jrmnlg3s

11:18 am
BE11:18am

What that report doesn't do is give any indication to what'll be in the report.

BE11:18am

Options are £50, £20, or £2 maximum stakes, which is quite a range.

BE11:19am

And a 12-week consultation before a final decision is made.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

So, in the absence of detail all we can do really is wait.

BE11:20am

Here's JPM, saying exactly that.

BE11:20am

In terms of potential impact on the gaming companies, we believe that this would bring little news, with the 3 retained options, if confirmed, still spanning a very wide range of outcomes, from relatively benign (JPMe below -6% machine market revenue impact) to
catastrophic (JPMe over -50% machine market revenue impact), and a maximum stake of around £20 remaining our central scenario. In terms of timing, the 12-week consultation period would take us to a late January decision. Overall UK gaming players could have more time than expected to put in place mitigation initiatives (JPMe previously final outcome by end November), but have shared very little so far on that theme.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And Barclays.

BE11:22am

In conclusion, we think LCL is materially oversold. Over the weekend there have been various press articles stating that the DCMS will finally publish a range of options for a reduction in maximum stakes for B2 fixed odds betting terminals. At last! We have been waiting all year for this announcement: it has been the key unknown holding back meaningful share price performance for Ladbrokes Coral and William Hill. A final figure is not expected to be confirmed but a range of £2, £20 and £50 is expected to be consulted on. Various publications state that £20 is a likely outcome. This outcome is in line with our thinking all year long: it represents a material headwind to the sector, shows the government is taking the issue seriously but does not lead to as material an impact on government tax/jobs/horse racing industry as a cut to £2 would have. Once the DCMS confirms the final figure for max stakes (post 12 week period), we think the companies impacted will quickly outline the impact on revenues/profits so that there is clarity for investors. We do not think either LCL or WMH will be left with a stretched balance sheet. As we have said consistently: following greater regulation will be M&A: that theme will dominate the debate in 2018: we think LCL, WMH and PPB will all be impacted by M&A.

BE11:22am

I mean, sure, we know the consolidation theme. We've talked about it endlessly.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Don't understand how you take a punt on it when the range of outcomes is so wide though.

BE11:23am

HSBC .....

BE11:23am

Bulls may point to greater certainty prompting the potential for more sector M&A. That’s possible, but we are not convinced that a) Risks have gone or b) That any deals will be struck above current share prices if the outcome is as bad as GBP2 per spin. In particular, we’d point to two risks in online that, to some extent are linked: The first is a possible review of online stakes and prizes: It makes no sense to stop gamblers making large wagers in shops if they are free to do it online. The second is potentially higher rates of online taxes, with remote gaming duty the easiest to change in the short term: UK rates are below international levels and we think this is an easy source of revenue for the Government, especially if it loses revenue as a result of lower usage of FOBTs.

11:23 am
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 126.00, up 1.7 (+1.37%), High: 126.00, Low: 123.10, Volume: 1.81m
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 251.60, up 2.6 (+1.04%), High: 252.60, Low: 246.50, Volume: 766.44k
GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 931.00, up 5 (+0.54%), High: 931.50, Low: 921.50, Volume: 258.84k
11:24 am
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 7,585, up 35 (+0.46%), High: 7,595, Low: 7,560, Volume: 5.30k
BE11:24am

Etc.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Easyjet requested on the right ....

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,305, up 32 (+2.51%), High: 1,309, Low: 1,284, Volume: 661.95k
BE11:25am

Which is on the back of the Air Berlin deal.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Taking over Air Berlin short-haul out of Tegel Airport, including leases for up to 25 A320 aircraft

PM11:27am

So this increases its fleet by close to 10 per cent

BE11:27am

More or less. And it's strategically useful as well as handy in terms of volume, according to sellside.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Barclays says ..............

BE11:27am

Berlin Tegel was Air Berlin’s largest base where it had a number one positioning, with c45% capacity share and c5.7mn shorthaul seats at peak and c4.5mn seats this year. On our anticipated FY19 seats flow, peak capacity would be

BE11:27am

This acquisition ties in with easyJet’s strategy to have number one or number two (to a strong legacy incumbent) market share at its bases. It is also worth noting that although easyJet has no current presence at Tegel airport, it does at the secondary airport in Berlin Schönefeld where it operates 2.9mn seats and has effectively joint number one market share with Ryanair. As and when Berlin Brandenburg airport opens (and Tegel likely closes), this number one market positioning will stand easyJet in good stead for slot allocation and positioning in the new airport, in our view.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

Full statement here btw: https://www.invest...1710300700028991U/

BE11:29am

Never flown into Tegel. Schönefeld is pretty good though. Half an hour into Neukölln, with only a bit of faffing about on buses.

BE11:30am

Canaccord as well, since we're here.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Actually, not Canaccord. It's dull. RBC's better.

BE11:31am

We think this will require an initial investment in likely lower fares and load factors as demand is rebuilt in the off-peak season - but offering scope to iron out any operational or transitional creases before reaching summer 2018 peak season.

BE11:31am

( Cheaper flights to Berlin! \o/ )

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Crucially to us, the new slots will give easyJet scope to optimize (as slot co-ordination and flight schedule season progress). It should then be able to change where it flies to and at what times and frequency it does so. Thus, the value is securing (grandfathered) slots at key (slot constrained) airports is more about what can be done with them, not what has been flown with them before. This can be done using an already established brand in the city.
An example would be to trim one frequency or route from a low contribution destination in time, to add another one to an existing route with market share potential from adding frequency. This would then offer scope for a disproportionate revenue and profit gain, potentially amplified if that allows say a Gatwick based A321 to run on the route.

BE11:31am

We see easyJet shares on ~14.6x 2017/18E PER. The forward multiple is above LCC peers and its 10-year median 11.7x, for a likely -6% 2017/18E equity FCF yield so the DPS yield of ~4% will likely be paid out of debt expansion, which we think the initial (re) start-up cost effects of the ex Air Berlin assets will amplify. Nevertheless, we see likely long-term upside in gaining a meaningful number of slots in a constrained market.

undefined
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Otherwise ..... housebuilders?

BE11:33am

Mostly down a tad.

PM11:33am

Sure (though you've skipped retail)

11:33 am
BE11:33am

(True. Though I was taking a more freeform approach.)

PM11:34am

ok, why are the housebuilders down?

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:34 am
BE11:34am

To a three-month low in September.

BE11:36am

Hang on, let me cut and paste the figures in from EY.

BE11:36am

The BoE reported that mortgage approvals for house purchases eased back for a second month running in September after hitting a six-month high in July.

Specifically, mortgage approvals dipped to 66,232 in September from 67,232 in August and a six-month high of 69,360 in July. It had previously spiked to July’s six-month high from a nine-month low of 65,664 in June. At 66,232 in September, mortgage approvals are still well below the average monthly level of 81,779 seen during 1993-2017.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Because the only comment I have to hand is YOY rather than MOM, which is a bit confusing.

BE11:37am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:37am

Mortgage approvals in September increased 3% vs Sept-16 and 7.5% vs Q3-16. Year-to-date approvals are now flat, and we expect a small increase for the full year. As a result, the transactions market should enter 2018 in slightly better shape than one may have expected earlier in the year. Nevertheless, we continue to prefer exposure to the new-build sector, and Help to Buy, across the residential space.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Meanwhile, arguably of greater importance is Barclays turning a bit more cautious on the sector.

BE11:38am

Downgrades of Bellway ....

Bellway PLC (BWY:LSE): Last: 3,649, down 49 (-1.33%), High: 3,650, Low: 3,532, Volume: 405.72k
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Berkeley ..........

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,729, down 78 (-2.05%), High: 3,737, Low: 3,664, Volume: 519.14k
BE11:38am

Persimmon .......

11:38 am
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,798, down 32.84 (-1.16%), High: 2,813, Low: 2,739, Volume: 745.95k
BE11:38am

Redrow .........

Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 645.50, down 2 (-0.31%), High: 646.50, Low: 630.50, Volume: 481.96k
11:38 am
BE11:38am

And TW.

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 201.00, down 0.9 (-0.45%), High: 201.44, Low: 197.70, Volume: 6.19m
BE11:39am

Valuation, plus political risk of some of the terrible policies being unwound a tad.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

One of Britain’s biggest ever post-election surveys revealed support for the government at its lowest among the young. Ahead of the Autumn Budget (Nov 22), we believe one key tenet (‘inter-generational fairness’) will be front and centre. Although measures could be impactful, history suggests that they can lack teeth (solving our ‘broken’ housing market is not easy) and we believe expectations may have run ahead of themselves. This, together with strong share price performance – our house builder index is up 46% YTD (vs. the FTSE 250 up 10%) – leads us to downgrade Persimmon and Berkeley (from EW to UW) and Redrow, Bellway and Taylor Wimpey (from OW to EW).

BE11:40am

The upshot here is that the young are revolting .....

PM11:40am

This is understandable

11:40 am
BE11:40am

BE11:41am

So, under the theme of "inter-generational fairness," we get stamp duty perks for first-time buyers ....

BE11:42am

(See last week on what little difference that'll make to volumes ....)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Along with relief for downsizers and maybe a bit of fiddling with HTB.

BE11:43am

Which is, according to Barclays "sucking demand from the wider market into the new build segment; elevating new build prices relative to their second hand equivalents; allowing people to buy more space than they otherwise would (at the
expense of subsequent transactions)."

BE11:43am

Despite this, we believe that the scheme is likely to remain the fulcrum of government policy before and after 2021. And, although we have yet to hear that the scheme will be extended beyond this date, this seems likely given the recent injection of £10bn more funding.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

So, yeah, valuation mostly. Plus a bit of risk that the dreadful policies that have bought a number of builder CEOs nice yachts might not last indefinitely.

undefined
BE11:45am

(@GBKrona: Thumbs up )

11:45 am
BE11:45am

What else? I see this AAAL thing happened.

PM11:46am

Ah yes, we should mention a $4bn deal

PM11:46am

Do you properly understand what AAA does?

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Yes. Yes I do.

PM11:46am

And why Novatis want it

PM11:46am

Great

11:46 am
BE11:46am

It's kind of an upgrade of somatostatin analogues.

BE11:47am

https://en.wikiped.../wiki/Somatostatin

PM11:47am

Ok...

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Switches off growth hormones .. and AAA has a thing in the pipeline called Lutathera, whose PhIII looks quite promising.

PM11:48am

At turning off tumours

BE11:49am

Tests have been extensive, more than 3k patients, and while you always have to be cautious about such data it does look interesting.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Or "they do look interesting", if you're a stickler for grammar. Here's JPM to summarise.

BE11:50am

Using our analyst Jessica Fye's forecasts for AAA, assumed synergies of $200m representing 50% of SG&A by 2021 (given Novartis already have a well established NET franchise which could sell Lutathera), cost of debt of 1% and deal closure at the end of 1Q’18, we find the acquisition 1% to 2.5% accretive through 2019 to 2021. The ROIC reaches 8.7% by 2021 which is comfortably above Novartis’ cost of capital. Overall we see the deal reinvigorating Novartis’ Neuroendocrine Tumour (NET) franchise, where their product Sandostatin LAR has been losing share to Ipsen’s Somatuline, providing Lutathera as a new growth driver. Thus we see this as a sensible bolt-on for Novartis and expect the shares up c. 1% this morning.

BE11:50am

AAA brings Lutathera for the treatment of GEP-NETs (somatostatin receptor positive gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors) which should boost the growth potential of Novartis’ NET franchise. Novartis’ Sandostatin LAR sales have been declining for the last year, due to competition from Ipsen’s Somatuline. While Lutathera does not address the decline of Sandosatin LAR directly, it should provide a new growth driver for the franchise. Novartis will be able to offer Lutathera to Sandostatin LAR/Somatuline failures based on the strong NETTER-1 data which showed a 79% reduction in PFS. Our AAA analyst Jessica Fye forecasts Lutathera sales reaching $310m in 2020, $390m in 2021 and $540m by 2025

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Should also note in passing that the punters were all over this one.

BE11:51am

Possibly on the back of a Bloomberg story back in September.

BE11:52am

But also, fair bit of gossip throughout the process. Mostly correct, as it turned out.

11:52 am
undefined
BE11:52am

Speaking of M&A ...........

BE11:53am

Good note from Credit Suisse this morning on the Tesco-Booker thing, which is likely to get CMA approval shortly.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

CS comes up with an interesting, not entirely obvious, suggestion on why Tesco's buying Booker: to close most of it.

BE11:53am

The logic here is that Tesco has 257 Extras, accounting for nearly half its UK floorspace.

BE11:54am

It grew the Extra line very rapidly since 2001, which was exactly the wrong strategy in a world moving more towards convenience stores ....

11:54 am
BE11:54am

... and the speed of expansion often resulted in them being in the wrong place.

BE11:54am

Which, as we've discussed many times over the past decade, leaves Tesco with a lot of fallow floorspace wanting filled.

BE11:54am

And previous attempts to fill it -- think the Giraffe acquisition -- haven't worked because people generally don't want to spend weekend leisure time in a Tesco the size of an aircraft carrier.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

So ......... why not move Booker into Tesco Extra's floorspace then sell off all the Booker stores?

PM11:55am

Hmm, nice idea

BE11:55am

Yep. CS has geospacialised the hell of this idea and found that three-quarters of Booker stores are within 10k of a Tesco Extra. Half are within 5k.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

BE11:55am

And since Booker leases 85% of its shops, Tesco can close them as the leases roll off. Same strategy as Sainsbury-Argos, in essence.

PM11:56am

Indeed

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Which saves a lot of cash.

BE11:56am

[Booker's] net operating lease expense was £57.3m in FY17, while its gross lease expense is expected to be £64m this year. If Booker was able to rationalise half of its space and incorporate that into Tesco current estate, gross lease expense could fall by as much as £38m per year.

BE11:56am

In 2016 Tesco paid £1.7bn to buy back leases that reduced its lease expense by £80m; using the same capitalisation rate, a £38m annual saving would be worth ~£800m.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

(@Mouselet: as to your first problem, that's Segro's concern.)

BE11:57am

Note that the figure there is hugely above Tesco guidance, which is for £200m of annual synergies by the end of Year 3.

BE11:57am

So anyway -- here's the Tesco-Booker map as it stands.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

BE11:57am

And here's the two-dozen Booker stores identified as too isolated to put into a Tesco Extra.

BE11:58am

11:58 am
BE11:58am

In spite of all this, CS remain sellers.

BE11:59am

Because closing 200 odd stores and ringfencing off your hypermarkets to sell wholesale next to retail won't be a breeze.

BE11:59am

Risks may shift from structural to execution. We are proponents of M&A within food retail and we like this transaction. It is large enough to matter and would provide a credible path for Tesco to work through its key problems. However, integrating two expansive, complex operations while reorganising a large part of its store estate is more challenging than the issues faced in other acquisitions (such as Sainsbury's recent takeover of Argos).

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Valuation. We have increased the potential Booker synergies to include a portion of lease cost savings estimate as well as Tesco/Booker's estimate of revenue synergies – both risked at 55% (up from 50%). We also increase our estimate for the likelihood of completion, from 85% to 95%. Our target price rises to 165p from 160p based on the increase in value of estimated synergies to Tesco shareholders (from £785m to £1.2bn). Our modified DCF- based valuation rises to £1.65/share; our rating remains Underperform.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 184.30, down 1.2 (-0.65%), High: 185.75, Low: 184.15, Volume: 4.97m
BE11:59am

Good note though. Recommended.

11:59 am
undefined
PM12:00pm

GIven the time, we should note this breaking US political news...

BE12:00pm

*MANAFORT IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN TOLD TO SURRENDER TO FEDS: NYT

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

WASHINGTON — Paul Manafort and his former business associate Rick Gates were told to surrender to federal authorities Monday morning, the first charges in a special counsel investigation, according to a person involved in the case.

The charges against Mr. Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, and Mr. Gates, a business associate of Mr. Manafort, were not immediately clear but represent a significant escalation in a special counsel investigation that has cast a shadow over the president’s first year in office.

PM12:00pm

https://www.nytime...fort-indicted.html

PM12:02pm

On that note...

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Are we done Bryce?

PM12:02pm

I think we are

PM12:03pm

Thanks for all that.

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp.

PM12:03pm

Bye

BE11:34am

So we have BOE mortgage approvals down for the second month.
